title: Building Secure Attachment
description: Discover how you're building a secure foundation together.

questions.text: What makes me feel most emotionally safe in our relationship?
choices: Freedom to express all my emotions
Knowing you won't leave during hard times

therapeutic.rationale: Emotional safety foundations vary by attachment history. Predictability-seekers need reliability; expression-freedom seekers need acceptance; won't-leave confidence addresses abandonment; calm-presence seekers need co-regulation. Creating your partner's specific safety conditions enables deeper intimacy.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different safety foundations need different creation. The predictability-seeker may not realize their partner needs expression freedom more than routine. Build your partner's safety, not your own projection.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared safety foundations make security easier. You understand what each other needs because you need the same things.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes you feel emotionally safe? Does your partner know? How can you create this safety for each other?

questions.text: How do I show that I trust you?
choices: Opening up about my deepest fears
Asking for help when I need it

therapeutic.rationale: Trust expression varies by attachment style. Fear-sharing shows emotional trust; freedom-giving shows secure attachment; help-asking shows dependency trust; vulnerability shows emotional openness. Recognizing how your partner shows trust helps you see it even when it differs from your expression.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different trust expressions may be missed. The freedom-giver may not realize their partner's vulnerability is a trust signal; the fear-sharer may not see freedom-giving as trust. Learn your partner's trust language.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared trust expressions make recognition easy. You see each other's trust because you show it the same way.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you show your partner you trust them? Do they recognize it? What's your clearest trust signal?

questions.text: What threatens my sense of trust most?
choices: Feeling shut out or kept at distance

therapeutic.rationale: Trust threats reveal attachment sensitivities. Inconsistency-sensitivity watches for reliability failures; shut-out sensitivity fears abandonment; communication-lack sensitivity needs transparency; broken-promise sensitivity needs follow-through. Knowing what threatens your partner's trust helps you avoid triggering it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different trust threats need different care. Your partner's sensitivity to broken promises may seem extreme if your sensitivity is to feeling shut out. Both are valid.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared trust threats mean you'll both react to the same triggers. Be extra careful with your shared vulnerability.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What most threatens your trust? Where does this sensitivity come from? Does your partner know to be careful here?

questions.text: How am I working on becoming more securely attached?
choices: Challenging old fears with new evidence

therapeutic.rationale: Secure attachment development follows different paths. Self-soothing work addresses co-dependency; direct communication replaces manipulation; small-step trust-building addresses avoidance; fear-challenging replaces old programming. Earned secure attachment is possible through intentional work.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different growth paths complement each other. The self-soothing worker grows in independence while the communication-learner grows in expression. Support each other's specific work.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared growth areas can be worked on together. You understand each other's challenges because you face the same ones.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How are you growing toward more secure attachment? What's working? What's still challenging?

questions.text: What's the greatest gift you give me in our relationship?
choices: Space to grow as an individual
Seeing and accepting my true self

therapeutic.rationale: Greatest relationship gifts reveal attachment healing. Unwavering presence addresses abandonment wounds; growth space addresses engulfment wounds; healing patience addresses self-judgment; true-self acceptance addresses shame wounds. What your partner values most tells you what wound you're helping heal.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different gifts valued mean you're each providing different healing. The presence-valuer receives abandonment healing; the space-valuer receives autonomy validation. Honor what your partner treasures.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared gift appreciation means you're healing similar wounds. You understand the gift's value because you need the same thing.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's the greatest gift your partner gives you? Have you told them? What attachment wound does this gift help heal?
